title: Cylinder Head - Installation

body.body: Warning - General - Stabilise Motorcycle Including locking devices
Warning - General - Stabilise Motorcycle - including DO NOT support on non integral parts
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
Note to be used in service manual with stabilise warning
Renew locking devices where specified, refer to
Before tightening a fixing using a crow foot spanner adapter, refer to
Use of Crow Foot Spanner Adapters with Torque Wrenches
Observe all torque wrench tightening procedures, refer to
Thoroughly clean the upper faces of the crankcase, taking care not to damage the mating surfaces.
Fit a new cylinder head gasket. Make sure that the cylinder head to crankcase location dowels are correctly in place.
Ensure that the cylinder head face is completely clean.
Carefully lower the cylinder head over the camshaft drive chain and locate the head onto the dowels.
Using the correct procedure to fit and tighten the cylinder head bolts will ensure the long term reliability of the cylinder head gasket.
Clean each new bolt, paying particular attention to the threads and under the bolt head areas. If any of the threads or bolt head areas are damaged, replace the bolt(s).
Tighten the bolts using the fiver-stage procedure given below.
Failure to observe these important items may lead to engine damage through a damaged head gasket.
Apply a thin layer of clean engine oil to the threads and under the heads of the new cylinder head bolts.
Fit the new bolts and washers to the cylinder head and tighten until finger tight.
The cylinder head bolts are tightened in five stages, in the sequence shown below. This is to make sure that the cylinder head gasket seals correctly to the cylinder head and crankcase.
For stages one, two and five of the bolt tightening operation, a torque wrench of known, accurate calibration must be used.
For stages three and four the bolts must be turned through a set number of degrees to reach the final setting. To accurately gauge the turn,
Tighten the cylinder head bolts, to
Tighten the cylinder head bolts to
Tighten the cylinder head bolts again to

between the Torx socket and the drive handle and locate the Torx drive to the bolts. Pick an increment point on the torque turn gauge which aligns with a suitable reference point on the cylinder head.
Tighten the cylinder head bolts to

Fit the cylinder head to upper crankcase screws located at the side of the cylinder head and tighten to

body.name: Cylinder Head to Upper Crankcase Screws (cdra.svg)

body.body: Cylinder head to upper crankcase screws
Install the camshaft drive chain tensioner blades. Install a new bolt to the front tensioner blade and tighten to
The tappet buckets and shims must be refitted in their original positions as noted during removal.

Clean and lubricate the tappet bucket(s) with a solution of engine oil and molybdenum disulphide grease in the proportions of 60 grammes of grease mixed with 930 cc of engine oil. Refit the tappet buckets and shims into their original positions.
Refit the coolant bypass hose to the rear of the cylinder head.

Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.

Tightening Procedures
Thoroughly clean the upper faces of the crankcase, taking care not to damage the mating surfaces.
Fit a new cylinder head gasket. Make sure that the cylinder head to crankcase location dowels are correctly in place.
Cylinder head gasket
Ensure that the cylinder head face is completely clean.
Carefully lower the cylinder head over the camshaft drive chain and locate the head onto the dowels.
Using the correct procedure to fit and tighten the cylinder head bolts will ensure the long term reliability of the cylinder head gasket.
Clean each new bolt, paying particular attention to the threads and under the bolt head areas. If any of the threads or bolt head areas are damaged, replace the bolt(s).
Tighten the bolts using the fiver-stage procedure given below.
Failure to observe these important items may lead to engine damage through a damaged head gasket.
Apply a thin layer of clean engine oil to the threads and under the heads of the new cylinder head bolts.
Fit the new bolts and washers to the cylinder head and tighten until finger tight.
The cylinder head bolts are tightened in five stages, in the sequence shown below. This is to make sure that the cylinder head gasket seals correctly to the cylinder head and crankcase.
For stages one, two and five of the bolt tightening operation, a torque wrench of known, accurate calibration must be used.
For stages three and four the bolts must be turned through a set number of degrees to reach the final setting. To accurately gauge the turn,
T3880105 - Torque Angle Gauge
must be used.

Tighten the cylinder head bolts, to
20 Nm

Tighten the cylinder head bolts to

in the sequence shown above.

in the sequence shown above.

between the Torx socket and the drive handle and locate the Torx drive to the bolts. Pick an increment point on the torque turn gauge which aligns with a suitable reference point on the cylinder head.

Install the camshaft drive chain tensioner blades. Install a new bolt to the front tensioner blade and tighten to
9 Nm
The tappet buckets and shims must be refitted in their original positions as noted during removal.

Clean and lubricate the tappet bucket(s) with a solution of engine oil and molybdenum disulphide grease in the proportions of 60 grammes of grease mixed with 930 cc of engine oil. Refit the tappet buckets and shims into their original positions.
Refit the coolant bypass hose to the rear of the cylinder head.
Perform the following operations:
Camshaft Drive Chain - Installation
Camshafts - Installation
Engine - Installation
